comments.body: Wouldn't this result no value for `-e`, i.e. `useradd -e USERNAME`, which is invalid? (I haven't tested it).

It is valid to pass an empty string to the `-e` param.

```
[root@lab-centos7 ~]# useradd testuser2 -e ''
[root@lab-centos7 ~]# ll /home
total 0
drwx------. 2 bob               users              62 Jun 27 19:00 bob
drwx------. 2 oracle            oinstall           62 Jun 26 00:15 oracle
drwx------. 2 testuser          testuser           62 Aug 15 16:07 testuser
drwx------. 2 testuser2         testuser2          62 Aug 16 20:57 testuser2
[root@lab-centos7 ~]# getent passwd testuser2
testuser2:x:1009:1011::/home/testuser2:/bin/bash
[root@lab-centos7 ~]# getent shadow testuser2
testuser2:!!:17759:0:99999:7:::
[root@lab-centos7 ~]# chage -l testuser2
Last password change					: Aug 16, 2018
Password expires					: never
Password inactive					: never
Account expires						: never
Minimum number of days between password change		: 0
Maximum number of days between password change		: 99999
Number of days of warning before password expires	: 7
```
We should only fetch user information with state `present`, there is no need to fetch user info if we are deleting a user.
If `user.state == 'absent'` the user account will be removed, which means `user.user_exists()` will be `False`. No need for the additional condition.

But it doesn't hurt to have this check, because we had an issue because of it. We had local users on our hosts and then we added those hosts into a FreeIPA domain. The FreeIPA domain had the same exact users that were created locally before, so when we deleted our local users using this module, what happened was that this condition returned `true` that the user did exist (because it found a user on the FreeIPA domain) and then it created that user's home dir.

For example if there is a `kustodian` local user and the `kustodian` user exists on the FreeIPA domain (or any central user management system), when you run:

```
- user:
    name: kustodian
    state: absent
```
This would delete the local `kustodian` user and then it would create the remote `kustodian` user home dir, which in our case was `/home/ipa.lan/kustodian`. Which is not what you expect from the `user` module to do when it deletes a user. Also it created the home dirs with `755`, which we also don't want (`useradd` creates them with 700). I know this is an edge case, but its something that can happen (it happened to us) and this additional condition solves the problem.
I see. Thank you for that great explanation. Since it doesnâ€™t hurt to have it plus fixes the scenario you describe, we should keep it.

This was an indentation bug, because it doesn't make sense to create the home dir, if it already exists, and it also doesn't make sense not to create it if `/etc/skell` doesn't exists, which was the case before.

There is no need to call `to_native` on an `int` since it ultimately uses `str()` on the value anyways. If anything the use of `str()` could be removed since it's also converted later:

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/6ac22416af987b4cd3e4cadf0f1d01352daf203c/lib/ansible/modules/system/user.py#L548
